description: From Middle French calenture, from Spanish calentura.

entries.meaning: A heat stroke or fever, often suffered in the tropics.
examples: To returne: in changing so many parallels, the weather increast from warme to raging hot, the Sunne flaming all day, insomuch that Calentures begun to vexe us.

entries.meaning: A delirium occurring from such symptoms, in which a stricken sailor pictures the sea as grassy meadows and wishes to dive overboard into them.
